        Deconstructing the Crystal Structures of Metal-Organic Frameworks and Related Materials into Their Underlying Nets
        O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 675-702CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Redn. of complex crystal structures of metal-org. frameworks and related materials to an underlying topol. is discussed. An approach to identify vertices of underlying nets is presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtFOmtr7L&md5=201baa336aa2d3edcb2099a649e840fe
        (b) Eubank, J. F.; Wojtas, L.; Hight, M. R.; Bousquet, T.; Kravtsov, V. C.; Eddaoudi, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 17532
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2b
        The Next Chapter in MOF Pillaring Strategies: Trigonal Heterofunctional Ligands To Access Targeted High-Connected Three Dimensional Nets, Isoreticular Platforms
        Eubank, Jarrod F.; Wojtas, Lukasz; Hight, Matthew R.; Bousquet, Till; Kravtsov, Victor Ch.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (44), 17532-17535CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A new pillaring strategy, based on a ligand-to-axial approach that combines the two previous common techniques, axial-to-axial and ligand-to-ligand, and permits design, access, and construction of higher dimensional MOFs, is introduced and validated. Trigonal heterofunctional ligands, in this case isophthalic acid cores functionalized at the 5-position with N-donor (e.g., pyridyl- or triazolyl-type) moieties, are designed and used to pillar pretargeted two-dimensional layers (supermol. building layers, SBLs). 5-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)isophthalic acid (H2L1) reacts with copper nitrate to form a L-A pillared sql-MOF, Cu-(L1) xsolv (1), based on nonequilateral triangles pillaring 2D layers of octahedra. Topol. anal. of the resultant [3,6]-connected net reveals 1 is the expected rtl-MOF. Reaction between copper nitrate and 5-(4-pyridinylmethoxy)isophthalic acid (H2L2) results in the expected L-A pillared kgm-MOF, Cu(L2) xsolv (2) which can also be viewed as a 3D MOF, where L2 serves as a 3-connected node and the paddlewheel cluster as a 6-connected octahedral node. These SBLs, based on edge transitive Kagome´ and square lattices, are cross-linked into predicted three-dimensional MOFs with tunable large cavities, resulting in isoreticular platforms.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXotVaksrk%253D&md5=a47460f9b4919554edc09910ab9d3f03
        (c) Park, J.; Wang, Z. U.; Sun, L.-B.; Chen, Y.-P.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 20110
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2c
        Functionalized mesopores to metal organic frameworks via metal ligand fragment coassembly
        Park, Jinhee; Wang, Zhiyong U.; Sun, Lin-Bing; Chen, Ying-Pin; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (49), 20110-20116CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Introduction of functionalized mesopores into microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) can endow them with suitable properties for applications in gas storage, sepn., catalysis, and drug delivery. However, common methods for functionalization (including pre- and post-synthetic modifications) of the internal surface of a MOF reduce the pore size of the MOF because the addnl. functional groups fill up the pores. We present a metal-ligand-fragment coassembly strategy for the introduction of (meso)pores functionalized with various substituent groups on the ligand fragments. Astonishingly, this new functionalization strategy increases the pore vol. of a MOF instead of reducing it. Since the ligand fragments are often readily available or easily prepd., the new procedure for synthesis of the modified MOFs becomes much easier and more applicable than existing approaches. Remarkably, mesopores can be generated conveniently and controllably by the coassembly of a ligand and its fragment contg. the desired functional groups. The fragment/ligand ratio has been optimized to preserve the parent structure and to promote max. mesopore introduction, which has led to a systematic evaluation of the effectiveness of a series of functional groups for the adsorption of guest mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhs12mtrzL&md5=0a4e24d55a6c9344eef8665a87a5bd62
        (d) Du, L.; Lu, Z.; Zheng, K.; Wang, J.; Zheng, X.; Pan, Y.; You, X.; Bai, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 562
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2d
        Fine-Tuning Pore Size by Shifting Coordination Sites of Ligands and Surface Polarization of Metal-Organic Frameworks To Sharply Enhance the Selectivity for CO2
        Du, Liting; Lu, Zhiyong; Zheng, Kaiyuan; Wang, Junyi; Zheng, Xin; Pan, Yi; You, Xiaozeng; Bai, Junfeng
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (2), 562-565CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Based upon the (3,6)-connected metal-org. framework {Cu(L1)·2H2O·1.5DMF}∞ (L1 = 5-(pyridin-4-yl)isophthalic acid) (SYSU, for Sun Yat-Sen University), iso-reticular {Cu(L2)·DMF}∞ (L2 = 5-(pyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai7; NJU-Bai for Nanjing University Bai group) and {Cu(L3)·DMF·H2O}∞ (L3 = 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai8) were designed by shifting the coordination sites of ligands to fine-tune pore size and polarizing the inner surface with uncoordinated N atoms, resp., with almost no changes in surface area or porosity. Compared with those of the prototype SYSU, both the adsorption enthalpy and selectivity of CO2 for NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 have been greatly enhanced, which makes NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 good candidates for postcombustion CO2 capture. Notably, the CO2 adsorption enthalpy of NJU-Bai7 is the highest reported so far among the MOFs without any polarizing functional groups or open metal sites. Meanwhile, NJU-Bai8 exhibits high uptake of CO2 and good CO2/CH4 selectivity at high pressure, which are quite valuable characteristics in the purifn. of natural gases.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvV2gsLvN&md5=95669e5c19fa61e7227828db666e414a
      3. 3
        (a) Demessence, A.; D’Alessandro, D. M.; Foo, M. L.; Long, J. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 8784
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3a
        Strong CO2 Binding in a Water-Stable, Triazolate-Bridged Metal-Organic Framework Functionalized with Ethylenediamine
        Demessence, Aude; D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Foo, Maw Lin; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (25), 8784-8786CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Reaction of CuCl2·2H2O with 1,3,5-tris(1H-1,2,3-triazol-5-yl)benzene (H3BTTri) in DMF at 100° generates the metal-org. framework H3[(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8(DMF)12]·7DMF·76H2O (1-DMF). The sodalite-type structure of the framework consists of BTTri3--linked [Cu4Cl]7+ square clusters in which each CuII center has a terminal DMF ligand directed toward the interior of a large pore. The framework exhibits a high thermal stability of up to 270°, as well as exceptional chem. stability in air, boiling water, and acidic media. Following exchange of the guest solvent and bound DMF mols. for methanol to give 1-MeOH, complete desolvation of the framework at 180° generated H3[(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8] (1) with exposed CuII sites on its surface. Following a previously reported protocol, ethylenediamine mols. were grafted onto these sites to afford 1-en, featuring terminal alkylamine groups. The N2 adsorption isotherms indicate a redn. in the BET surface area from 1770 to 345 m2/g following grafting. The H2 adsorption data at 77 K for 1 indicate a fully reversible uptake of 1.2% at 1.2 bar, while the CO2 isotherm at 195 K shows a maximal uptake of 90% at 1 bar. Compared to 1, the alkylamine-functionalized framework 1-en exhibits a higher uptake of CO2 at 298 K and pressures up to ∼0.1 bar, as well as a higher CO2/N2 selectivity at all measured pressures. Significantly, 1-en also exhibits an isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption of 90 kJ/mol, which is much higher than the 21 kJ/mol obsd. for 1. This chemisorption interaction is the strongest reported to date for a metal-org. framework and points toward the potential utility of alkylamine-appended frameworks for the post-combustion capture of CO2 from low-pressure flue gas streams.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXmvFWqtrY%253D&md5=da2f3e278125e096f509e1e4618d9387
        (b) Prasad, T. K.; Hong, D. H.; Suh, M. P. Chem.—Eur. J. 2010, 16, 14043
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3b
        High Gas Sorption and Metal-Ion Exchange of Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Incorporated Imide Groups
        Prasad, Thazhe Kootteri; Hong, Dae Ho; Suh, Myunghyun Paik
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2010), 16 (47), 14043-14050, S14043/1-S14043/27CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), [Cu2(bdcppi)(DMF)2]·10DMF·2H2On (SNU-50) and [Zn2(bdcppi)(DMF)3]·6DMF·4H2On (SNU-51), were prepd. by the solvothermal reactions of N,N'-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)pyromellitic diimide (H4BDCPPI) with Cu(NO3)2 and Zn(NO3)2, resp. Framework SNU-50 has an NbO-type net structure, whereas SNU-51 has a PtS-type net structure. Desolvated solid [Cu2(bdcppi)]n (SNU-50'), which was prepd. by guest exchange of SNU-50 with acetone followed by evacuation at 170°, adsorbs high amts. of N2, H2, O2, CO2, and CH4 gases due to the presence of a vacant coordination site at every metal ion, and to the presence of imide groups in the ligand. The Langmuir surface area is 2450 m2 g-1. It adsorbs H2 gas up to 2.10% at 1 atm and 77 K, with zero coverage isosteric heat of 7.1 kJ mol-1, up to a total of 7.85% at 77 K and 60 bar. Its CO2 and CH4 adsorption capacities at 298 K are 77% at 55 bar and 17% at 60 bar, resp. Of particular note is the O2 adsorption capacity of SNU-50' (118% at 77 K and 0.2 atm), which is the highest reported so far for any MOF. By metal-ion exchange of SNU-51 with CuII, [Cu2(bdcppi)(DMF)3]·7DMF·5H2On (SNU-51-CuDMF) with a PtS-type net was prepd., which could not be synthesized by a direct solvothermal reaction.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsFCktr7J&md5=d668df9e24808f1f95d39f584e4028d3
        (c) Banerjee, R.; Furukawa, H.; Britt, D.; Knobler, C.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 3875
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3c
        Control of Pore Size and Functionality in Isoreticular Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks and their Carbon Dioxide Selective Capture Properties
        Banerjee, Rahul; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Britt, David; Knobler, Carolyn; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (11), 3875-3877CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new cryst. zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), ZIF-78 to -82, were prepd. from zinc(II) nitrate and mixts. of 2-nitroimidazole and five different functionalized imidazoles and were found to have the GME topol. These structures, along with three previously reported GME ZIFs, constitute a series of highly porous materials with Brunauer-Emmet-Teller surface areas ranging from 620 to 1730 m2/g. The pore diams. and apertures vary incrementally from 7.1 to 15.9 Å and 3.8 to 13.1 Å, resp., and the functionalities decorating the pores vary from polar cyano- and nitro- groups to nonpolar alkyl groups. The variability expressed in these materials makes them highly attractive for study as gas-sepn. media. Selectivity values calcd. for sepn. of CO2 and CH4 predict that the ZIFs with polar functionality, ZIF-78 (10.6:1) and -82 (9.6:1), retain CO2 gas to a greater degree than the other members of the GME series and BPL-activated carbon. These predictions are borne out in dynamic breakthrough studies, which confirm the increased capacity of ZIF-78 and -82 and demonstrate the promise of this class of materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXisFans7s%253D&md5=5fba32f296b7f0cf32e22fa84b98af89
        (d) Deng, H. X.; Doonan, C. J.; Furukawa, H.; Ferreira, R. B.; Towne, J.; Knobler, C. B.; Wang, B.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2010, 327, 846
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3d
        Multiple Functional Groups of Varying Ratios in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Deng, Hexiang; Doonan, Christian J.; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Ferreira, Ricardo B.; Towne, John; Knobler, Carolyn B.; Wang, Bo; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 327 (5967), 846-850CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) can incorporate a large no. of different functionalities on linking groups in a way that mixes the linker, rather than forming sep. domains. The authors made complex MOFs from 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (denoted by A in this work) and its derivs. -NH2, -Br, -(Cl)2, -NO2, -Me2, -C4H4, -(OC3H5)2, and -(OC7H7)2 (denoted by B to I,, resp.) to synthesize 18 multivariate (MTV) MOF-5 type structures that contain up to eight distinct functionalities in one phase. The backbone (Zn oxide and phenylene units) of these structures is ordered, but the distribution of functional groups is disordered. The complex arrangements of several functional groups within the pores can lead to properties that are not simply linear sums of those of the pure components. For example, a member of this series, MTV-MOF-5-EHI, exhibits up to 400% better selectivity for CO2 over CO compared with its best same-link counterparts.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhslWju7o%253D&md5=40f9720d9a7633e6102cab3256be0468
        (e) Zhao, X. L.; Sun, D.; Yuan, S.; Feng, S.; Cao, R.; Yuan, D.; Wang, S.; Dou, J.; Sun, D. Inorg. Chem. 2012, 51, 10350
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3e
        Comparison of the Effect of Functional Groups on Gas-Uptake Capacities by Fixing the Volumes of Cages A and B and Modifying the Inner Wall of Cage C in rht-Type MOFs
        Zhao, XiaoLiang; Sun, Di; Yuan, Shuai; Feng, Shengyu; Cao, Rong; Yuan, Daqiang; Wang, Suna; Dou, Jianmin; Sun, Daofeng
        Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (19), 10350-10355CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three porous (3,24)-connected rht-type metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), [Cu3L(H2O)3]·xsolvents (H6LOH = 4,4',4''-(hydroxysilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-3,5-dicarboxylic acid), SDU-6; H6LMe = 4,4',4''-(methylsilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-3,5-dicarboxylic acid), SDU-7; H6LiBu = 4,4',4''-(isobutylsilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-3,5-dicarboxylic acid), SDU-8), were successfully prepd. from [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs (secondary building units) and C3-sym. Si-based hexatopic carboxylate linkers. All porous MOFs are constructed from 3-dimensional packing of nanosized cuboctahedral, truncated tetrahedral, and truncated octahedral cages. SDU-6-8 differ only in the functionality of the central Si atom of the hexacarboxylate ligands with hydroxyl, Me, and iso-Bu groups, resp. Gas adsorption measurements of activated MOFs suggested that decoration of the cage walls with strong polar groups can enhance the adsorption capacities for N2, H2, and CH4. SDU-6 with -OH as the functional group possesses high CH4 uptake (172 cm3 cm-3 at 35 bar), which is very close to DOE target of 180 cm3 cm-3.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtlOjtbbO&md5=60009ae63cca5858a9a223044f9aea10
      4. 4
        (a) Liu, B.; Yang, Q. Y.; Xue, C. Y.; Zhong, C. L.; Chen, B. H.; Smit, B. J. Phys. Chem. C 2008, 112, 9854
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4a
        Enhanced Adsorption Selectivity of Hydrogen/Methane Mixtures in Metal-Organic Frameworks with Interpenetration: A Molecular Simulation Study
        Liu, Bei; Yang, Qingyuan; Xue, Chunyu; Zhong, Chongli; Chen, Biaohua; Smit, Berend
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2008), 112 (26), 9854-9860CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        A systematic mol. simulation study was performed to study the effect of interpenetration on gas mixt. sepn. in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). To do this, 3 pairs of isoreticular MOFs (IRMOFs) with and without interpenetration were adopted to compare their adsorption sepn. selectivity for CH4/H2 mixts. at room temp. Methane selectivity is greatly enhanced in the interpenetrated IRMOFs compared with their noninterpenetrated counterparts, due to the formation of addnl. small pores and adsorption sites by the interpenetration of frameworks. Also, this work shows methane selectivity behavior is more complex in the former and selectivity differs largely in the different areas of the pores, attributed to the existence of various small pores of different sizes. The present work shows the ideal adsorbed soln. theory probably is applicable to interpenetrated MOFs with complex structures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXmvFCiur4%253D&md5=38a6fe7ae63ca47e2ec3765168026f3e

        4b
        Selective gas adsorption in a magnesium-based metal-organic framework
        Cheon, Young Eun; Park, Jungeun; Suh, Myunghyun Paik
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2009), (36), 5436-5438CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A doubly interpenetrated magnesium-based porous metal-org. framework exhibits thermal stability up to 500° and selective gas sorption properties for H2 and O2 gases over N2, and CO2 gas over CH4.

        4c
        Control of catenation in CuTATB-n metal-organic frameworks by sonochemical synthesis and its effect on CO2 adsorption
        Kim, Jun; Yang, Seung-Tae; Choi, Sang Beom; Sim, Jaeung; Kim, Jaheon; Ahn, Wha-Seung
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2011), 21 (9), 3070-3076CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The metal-org. frameworks CuTATB-n (TATB = 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoate; n = power level) having either catenated (CuTATB-60) or noncatenated (CuTATB-30) structure were synthesized in 1 h via a novel sonochem. route. The control of catenation was achieved by simple adjustment of the ultrasonic power levels. The x-ray diffraction patterns, BET surface areas (3778 and 2477 m2 g-1, resp.) and pore vols., and TGA patterns of the individual product obtained were in agreement with the published literature data of the corresponding materials known as PCN-6 (catenated) and PCN-6' (noncatenated). Catenation of the two identical networks within large pores resulted in both high surface area and enhanced stability of the network. Such control of catenation was addnl. demonstrated by successful synthesis of IRMOF-9 (catenated) and IRMOF-10 (noncatenated) pair by the same sonochem. method. CO2 adsorption properties of the CuTATB-n were measured at 273 and 298 K, which indicated the contribution of catenation in CuTATB-n for CO2 capture. The adsorption isotherms for CO2 and N2 show high adsorption capacity for CO2 (189 mg g-1 and 156 mg g-1, resp. for CuTATB-60 and -30 at 298 K) and excellent selectivity over N2 (>20:1). Five consecutive adsorption-desorption runs performed using high purity CO2 in a flow system established no deterioration in the adsorption capacity of CuTATB-60, which showed reversible adsorbent regeneration at 75° under He flow and excellent stability for a total duration of 800 min. CuTATB-60 also demonstrated high gas adsorption capacity (1171 mgCO2 g-1adsorbent) at 30 bar and 298 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhvFCiur8%253D&md5=56880c9b01e2366616f257bb31cd32f3
      5. 5
        (a) Burd, S. D.; Ma, S. Q.; Perman, J. A.; Sikora, B. J.; Snurr, R. Q.; Thallapally, P. K.; Tian, J.; Wojtas, L.; Zaworotko, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 3663
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5a
        Highly Selective Carbon Dioxide Uptake by [Cu(bpy-n)2(SiF6)] (bpy-1 = 4,4'-Bipyridine; bpy-2 = 1,2-Bis(4-pyridyl)ethene)
        Burd, Stephen D.; Ma, Shengqian; Perman, Jason A.; Sikora, Benjamin J.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Thallapally, Praveen K.; Tian, Jian; Wojtas, Lukasz; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (8), 3663-3666CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A previously known class of porous coordination polymer (PCP), [Cu(bpy-n)2(SiF6)] (bpy-1 = 4,4'-bipyridine; bpy-2 = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene), was studied to assess its selectivity toward CO2, CH4, N2, and H2O. Both polymers were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. Gas sorption measurements reveal that [Cu(bpy-1)2(SiF6)] exhibits the highest uptake for CO2 yet seen at 298 K and 1 atm by a PCP that does not contain open metal sites. Significantly, [Cu(bpy-1)2(SiF6)] does not exhibit particularly high uptake under the same conditions for CH4, N2, and, H2O, presumably because of its lack of open metal sites. Consequently, at 298 K and 1 atm [Cu(bpy-1)2(SiF6)] exhibits a relative uptake of CO2 over CH4 of ∼10.5:1, the highest value exptl. obsd. in a compd. without open metal sites. [Cu(bpy-2)2(SiF6)] exhibits larger pores and surface area than [Cu(bpy-1)2(SiF6)] but retains a high CO2/CH4 relative uptake of ∼8:1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XitVequrY%253D&md5=7bcf90e89c81065912bdd453d45db63e

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5b
        Rationally Designed Micropores within a Metal-Organic Framework for Selective Sorption of Gas Molecules
        Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Zapata, Fatima; Fronczek, Frank R.; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (4), 1233-1236CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A microporous metal-org. framework, MOF, Cu(FMA)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5 (3a, FMA = fumarate; 4,4'-Bpe = 4,4'-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) was rationally designed from a primitive cubic net whose pores are tuned by double framework interpenetration. With pore cavities of about 3.6 Å, which are interconnected by pore windows of 2.0 × 3.2 Å, 3a shows highly selective sorption behaviors of gas mols.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5c
        A Metal-Organic Framework with Optimized Open Metal Sites and Pore Spaces for High Methane Storage at Room Temperature
        Guo, Zhiyong; Wu, Hui; Srinivas, Gadipelli; Zhou, Yaming; Xiang, Shengchang; Chen, Zhenxia; Yang, Yongtai; Zhou, Wei; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2011), 50 (14), 3178-3181, S3178/1-S3178/10CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A 3D porous metal-org. framework (MOF) complex (UTSA-20) based on a novel trinodal (3,3,4) net of zyg topol. by the self-assembly of the nonlinear hexacarboxylate (BHB) with the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 cluster was prepd. Although its porosity and surface area are moderate and much lower than those of most highly porous MOFs, the open copper sites and optimal pore spaces within UTSA-20 have enabled the pore spaces to be fully utilized for methane storage, featuring UTSA-20 as the material with the highest methane storage d. (0.222 g·cm-3), and just the third porous MOF whose abs. volumetric methane storage has surpassed the DOE methane storage target of 180 cm3cm-3 at room temp. and 35 bar. By the immobilization of a high d. of open metal sites and the deliberate control of the pore space for their efficient methane storage, these new porous MOFs are envisioned to be promising media for methane and natural gas storage, particularly for mobile applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        An expanded 4,4-paddlewheel-connected porous MOF-505-type metal-org. framework (MOF), [Cu2(PDEB)(H2O)2]·xS (NJU-Bai12; NJU-Bai = the Nanjing University Bai group, S = noncoordinated solvent mols.) was designed from a nanosized rectangular diisophthalate linker contg. alkyne groups (PDEB = 5,5'-(1,4-phenylenedi-2,1-ethynediyl)bis(1,3-benzenecarboxylic acid)). This MOF material possesses permanent microporosity with the highest Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 3038 m2 g-1 and the largest unsatd. total H storage capacity of 62.7 mg g-1 at 77 K and 20 bar among reported MOF-505 analogs.         A highly porous 4,4-paddlewheel-connected NbO-type metal-organic framework with a large gas-uptake capacity

HNUST-2 exhibits high structural stability, a porous non-interpenetration framework with open metal sites and excellent gas-uptake capacity.       7. 7
        Sheldrick, G. M. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A 2008, 64, 112
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        A short history of SHELX
        Sheldrick, George M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
        An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
      8. 8
        Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9a
        Exceptionally high H2 storage by a metal-organic polyhedral framework
        Yan, Yong; Lin, Xiang; Yang, Sihai; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroeder, Martin

        The de-solvated polyhedral framework material, NOTT-112, shows an excess H2 uptake of 7.07% between 35 and 40 bar at 77 K, and a total H2 uptake of 10% at 77 bar and 77 K.

        (b) Collins, D. J.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Mater. Chem. 2007, 17, 3154
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9b
        Hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Collins, David J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2007), 17 (30), 3154-3160CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. For any potential hydrogen-storage system, raw uptake capacity must be balanced with the kinetics and thermodn. of uptake and release. Metal-org. frameworks provide unique systems with large overall pore vols. and surface areas, adjustable pore sizes, and tunable framework-adsorbate interaction by ligand functionalization and metal choice. These remarkable materials can potentially fill the niche between other physisorbents such as activated carbon, which have similar uptake at low temps. but low affinity for hydrogen at ambient temp., and chem. sorbents such as hydrides, which have high hydrogen uptakes but undesirable release kinetics and thermodn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXotV2lt7c%253D&md5=211f2f55436d52593c4f7d9b8939bee6

        [Crossref], Google Scholar

        An interweaving Cu metal-org. framework possessing high porosity and high H uptake was successfully designed and synthesized. Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3 (TATB = 4,4',4"-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tribenzoate) was prepd., its structure detd. and its hydrogen adsorption characteristics also detd.

        A copper-based metal-org. framework (MOF) has been synthesized, and its structure has been solved by X-ray crystallog. The remarkably high hydrogen adsorption properties (2.47 wt%) of this compd. have been studied.

        10c
        High H2 adsorption by coordination-framework materials
        Lin, Xiang; Jia, Junhua; Zhao, Xuebo; Thomas, K. Mark; Blake, Alexander J.; Walker, Gavin S.; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroeder, Martin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (44), 7358-7364CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Three coordination frameworks with different pore sizes were prepd. from CuII salt and carboxylate ligands of various lengths. Comparison of their sorption properties reveals that smaller pores allow higher densities of adsorbed H2, whereas larger pores allow higher max. H2 storage capacities. The structures of the three structural analogs are also reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xht1OmsbvI&md5=35c0082804c53403f9f34067950b76a6

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10d
        Metal-Organic Framework from an Anthracene Derivative Containing Nanoscopic Cages Exhibiting High Methane Uptake
        Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Simmons, Jason M.; Collier, Christopher D.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (3), 1012-1016CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A microporous metal-org. framework, PCN-14, based on an anthracene deriv., 5,5'- (9,10-anthracene-diyl)di-isophthalate (H4adip), was synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. X-ray single crystal anal. revealed that PCN-14 consists of nanoscopic cages suitable for gas storage. N2-adsorption studies of PCN-14 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 2176 m2/g and a pore vol. of 0.87 cm3/g. Methane adsorption studies at 290 K and 35 bar show that PCN-14 exhibits an abs. methane-adsorption capacity of 230 vol./vol., 28% higher than the DOE target (180 vol./vol.) for methane storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlymug%253D%253D&md5=47684d1faab210ef528aa92e5e5754a3
        (e) Luo, J.; Xu, H.; Liu, Y.; Zhao, Y.; Daemen, L. L.; Brown, C.; Timofeeva, T. V.; Ma, S.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 9626
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10e
        Hydrogen Adsorption in a Highly Stable Porous Rare-Earth Metal-Organic Framework: Sorption Properties and Neutron Diffraction Studies
        Luo, Junhua; Xu, Hongwu; Liu, Yun; Zhao, Yusheng; Daemen, Luke L.; Brown, Craig; Timofeeva, Tatiana V.; Ma, Shengqian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (30), 9626-9627CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A highly stable porous lanthanide metal-org. framework, Y(BTC)(H2O)·4.3H2O (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), with pore size of 5.8 Å has been constructed and investigated for hydrogen storage. Gas sorption measurements show that this porous metal-org. framework exhibits highly selective sorption behaviors of hydrogen over nitrogen gas mols. and can take up hydrogen of ∼2.1 wt.% at 77 K and 10 bar. Difference Fourier anal. of neutron powder diffraction data revealed four distinct D2 sites that are progressively filled within the nanoporous framework. Interestingly, the strongest adsorption sites identified are assocd. with the arom. org. linkers rather than the open metal sites, as occurred in previously reported metal-org. frameworks. Our results provide for the first time direct structural evidence demonstrating that optimal pore size (∼6 Å, twice the kinetic diam. of hydrogen) strengthens the interactions between H2 mols. and pore walls and increases the heat of adsorption, which thus allows for enhancing hydrogen adsorption from the interaction between hydrogen mols. with the pore walls rather than with the normally stronger adsorption sites (the open metal sites) within the framework. At high concn. H2 loadings (5.5 H2 mols. (3.7 wt.%) per Y(BTC) formula), H2 mols. form highly sym. novel nanoclusters with relatively short H2-H2 distances compared to solid H2. These observations are important and hold the key to optimizing this new class of rare metal-org. framework materials for practical hydrogen storage applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXot1ahsLY%253D&md5=cea045a6078dd9a155f4cac197b772f1
        (f) Xue, M.; Zhu, G.; Li, Y.; Zhao, X.; Jin, Z.; Kang, E.; Qiu, S.-L. Cryst. Growth Des. 2008, 8, 2478
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10f
        Structure, Hydrogen Storage, and Luminescence Properties of Three 3D Metal-Organic Frameworks with NbO and PtS Topologies
        Xue, Ming; Zhu, Guangshan; Li, Yangxue; Zhao, Xiaojun; Jin, Zhao; Kang, Enhua; Qiu, Shilun
        Crystal Growth & Design (2008), 8 (7), 2478-2483CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Three 3-dimensional multifunctional microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) (H4ABTC = 3,3',5,5'-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N'-DMF, and JUC = Jilin University China) were synthesized by self-assembly of a rigid tetra-carboxylate ligand H4ABTC and corresponding transition metal salts under mild conditions. X-ray crystallog. reveals that their topologies are based on NbO (JUC-62) and PtS (JUC-63 and JUC-64) nets, constructed of 4-connected rectangular ABTC4- units with 4-connected square paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 secondary building units (SBUs), tetrahedral bimetallic Cd2(CO2)4(DMF)3 SBUs, and tetrahedral monometallic Mn(CO2)4(DMF)3 SBUs, resp. High-pressure H2 sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is satd. at 40 bar with a H2 uptake of ∼4.71%. Photoluminescence studies reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        10g
        A comparison of the H2 sorption capacities of isostructural metal-organic frameworks with and without accessible metal sites: [{Zn2(abtc)(dmf)2}3] and [{Cu2(abtc)(dmf)2}3] versus [{Cu2(abtc)}3]
        Lee, Yong-Gon; Moon, Hoi Ri; Cheon, Young Eun; Suh, Myunghyun Paik
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (40), 7741-7745CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The isostructural metal-org. frameworks [{Zn2(abtc)(dmf)2}3], [{Cu2(abtc)(dmf)2}3], and [{Cu2(abtc)}3], where H4abtc is 1,1'-azobenzene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid, have high sorption capacities for H2, N2, CO2, and CH4. Solid [{Cu2(abtc)}3], which has accessible metal sites, has a higher H2 adsorption capacity than [{Zn2(abtc)(dmf)2}3] or [{Cu2(abtc)(dmf)2}3], neither of which have accessible metal sites, because of its lower mol. wt. and greater isosteric heat of H2 adsorption.

        10h
        Enhancing H2 uptake by "close-packing" alignment of open copper sites in metal-organic frameworks
        Wang, Xi-Sen; Ma, Shengqian; Forster, Paul M.; Yuan, Daqiang; Eckert, Juergen; Lopez, Joseph J.; Murphy, Brandon J.; Parise, John B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (38), 7263-7266CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Inspired by close-packing of spheres, to strengthen the framework-H2 interaction in MOFs (metal-org. frameworks), a strategy is devised to increase the no. of nearest neighboring open metal sites of each H2-hosting cage, and to align the open metal sites toward the H2 mols. Two MOF polymorphs were made, one exhibiting a record high hydrogen uptake of 3.0 wt% at 1 bar and 77 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtFyqsbfP&md5=926efc2ad02252fab5b7e81cc4480f7e
        (i) Wang, X. S.; Ma, S.; Rauch, K.; Simmons, J. M.; Yuan, D.; Wang, X.; Yildirim, T.; Cole, W. C.; Lopez, J. L.; Meijere, A.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Mater. 2008, 20, 3145
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10i
        Metal-organic frameworks based on double-bond-coupled di-isophthalate linkers with high hydrogen and methane uptakes
        Wang, Xi-Sen; Ma, Shengqian; Rauch, Karsten; Simmons, Jason M.; Yuan, Daqiang; Wang, Xiaoping; Yildirim, Taner; Cole, William C.; Lopez, Joseph J.; de Meijere, Armin; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemistry of Materials (2008), 20 (9), 3145-3152CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2 with azoxybenzene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4aobtc) or trans-stilbene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4sbtc) give rise to two isostructural microporous metal-org. frameworks, Cu2(abtc)(H2O)2·3DMA (PCN-10, abtc = azobenzene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylate) and Cu2(sbtc)(H2O)2·3DMA (PCN-11, sbtc = trans-stilbene-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylate), resp. Both PCN-10 and PCN-11 possess significant enduring porosity with Langmuir surface areas of 1779 and 2442 m2/g (corresponding to BET surface areas of 1407 or 1931 m2/g, resp.) and contain nanoscopic cages and coordinatively unsatd. metal centers. At 77 K, 760 torr, the excess gravimetric (volumetric) H uptake of PCN-10 is 2.34% (18.0 g/L) and that of PCN-11 can reach 2.55% (19.1 g/L). Gas-adsorption studies also suggest that MOFs contg. C=C double bonds are more favorable than those with N=N double bond in retaining enduring porosity after thermal activation, although N=N has slightly higher H2 affinity. The excess gravimetric (volumetric) adsorption at 77 K sats. around 20 atm and reaches values of 4.33% (33.2 g/L) and 5.05% (37.8 g/L) for PCN-10 and PCN-11, resp. In addn. to its appreciable H uptake, PCN-11 has an excess methane uptake of 171 cm3(STP)/cm3 at 298 K and 35 bar, approaching the DOE target of 180 v(STP)/v for methane storage at ambient temp. Thus, PCN-11 represents one of the few materials that is applicable to both H and methane storage applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10j
        High Capacity Hydrogen Adsorption in Cu(II) Tetracarboxylate Framework Materials: The Role of Pore Size, Ligand Functionalization, and Exposed Metal Sites
        Lin, Xiang; Telepeni, Irvin; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Brown, Craig M.; Simmons, Jason M.; Zoppi, Marco; Walker, Gavin S.; Thomas, K. Mark; Mays, Timothy J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (6), 2159-2171CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Isostructural metal-org. framework polymers [Cu2(L)(H2O)2] (L = tetracarboxylate ligands), denoted NOTT-nnn, were synthesized and characterized. Single crystal x-ray structures confirm the complexes to contain binuclear Cu(II) paddlewheel nodes each bridged by four carboxylate centers to give a NbO-type network of 64·82 topol. These complexes are activated by solvent exchange with acetone coupled to heating cycles under vacuum to afford the desolvated porous materials NOTT-100 to NOTT-109. These incorporate a vacant coordination site at each Cu(II) center and have large pore vols. that contribute to the obsd. high H2 adsorption. Indeed, NOTT-103 at 77 K and 60 bar shows a very high total H2 adsorption of 77.8 mg g-1 equiv. to 7.78% [wt% = (wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material)] or 7.22% [wt% = 100(wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material + wt. of adsorbed H2)]. Neutron powder diffraction studies on NOTT-101 reveal three adsorption sites for this material: at the exposed Cu(II) coordination site, at the pocket formed by three {Cu2} paddle wheels, and at the cusp of three Ph rings. Systematic virial anal. of the H2 isotherms suggests that the H2 binding energies at these sites are very similar and the differences are smaller than 1.0 kJ mol-1, although the adsorption enthalpies for H2 at the exposed Cu(II) site are significantly affected by pore metrics. Introducing Me groups or using kinked ligands to create smaller pores can enhance the isosteric heat of adsorption and improve H2 adsorption. However, although increasing the overlap of potential energy fields of pore walls increases the heat of H2 adsorption at low pressure, it may be detrimental to the overall adsorption capacity by reducing the pore vol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXptlOitQ%253D%253D&md5=cbc9f02158801ff5dacb7df033416d78
        (k) Sun, D.; Ma, S.; Simmons, J. M.; Li, J.-R.; Yuan, D.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Commun. 2010, 46, 1329

        An unusual case of symmetry-preserving isomerism
        Sun, Daofeng; Ma, Shengqian; Simmons, Jason M.; Li, Jian-Rong; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (8), 1329-1331CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two isomeric phases of the NbO-type structure, PCN-16 (α phase) and PCN-16' (β phase), with compns. Cu2(H2O)2(ebdc)·3DMA·6H2O (α phase, H4ebdc = bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)ethyne) and Cu2(H2O)2(ebdc)·3DMF·6H2O (β phase), were prepd. and the desolvated isomers were characterized by x-ray crystallog. The isomeric phases are assemblies of dicopper paddlewheel SBUs with the tetracarboxylate ligand. Gas sorption studies revealed that the α phase possesses a larger surface area, leading to higher hydrogen and methane storage capacity as compared with the β phase.

        Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (19), 10720-10722CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)

The compds. with removal of solvents and coordinated H2O possess large surface areas and high CO2 adsorption capacities (up to 170 cm3/g or 7.59 mmol/g at 0° under ambient pressure).

        Hydrogen-storage materials for mobile applications
        Schlapbach, Louis; Zuettel, Andreas

        A review of recent developments in the search for innovative materials with high hydrogen-storage capacity. Conventional hydrogen storage, hydrogen adsorption on solids of large surface area, and hydrogen storage in metal hydrides are discussed.

        11b
        Review of Methane Mitigation Technologies with Application to Rapid Release of Methane from the Arctic
        Stolaroff, Joshuah K.; Bhattacharyya, Subarna; Smith, Clara A.; Bourcier, William L.; Cameron-Smith, Philip J.; Aines, Roger D.
        Environmental Science & Technology (2012), 46 (12), 6455-6469CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
        A review concerning CH4 emission sources and mitigation technologies for applications related to rapid CH4 release in the Arctic is given. Overall, 4 avenues of research and development which serve the dual purpose of addressing current CH4 and potential Arctic sources are: CH4 release detection and quantification; mitigation units for small/remote CH4 streams; mitigation methods for dil. CH4 streams (<1000 ppm); and understanding methanotrophs and methanogen ecol. Topics discussed include: current CH4 emission sources (methanogenesis, fossil CH4, incomplete combustion); mitigation strategy review (confined, area, aq., and unconfined sources); potential rapid CH4 release sources (aq. sources [ocean and eastern Siberian Arctic shelf clathrates, eastern Siberian Arctic shelf sediment, Arctic lakes], area sources [wetlands, terrestrial permafrost]); option assessment (Arctic sources, current sources and common development paths); conclusions; and supporting information (assessment of scale for atm. CH4 capture [industrial capture, catalytic properties], summary of Arctic source ests.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Han, S. S.; Mendoza-Cortés, J. L.; Goddard, W. A., III Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1460

        12
        Recent advances on simulation and theory of hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks and covalent organic frameworks
        Han, Sang Soo; Mendoza-Cortes, Jose L.; Goddard, William A., III
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1460-1476CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This review covers the application of computer simulations, including quantum calcns. (ab initio and DFT), grand canonical Monte-Carlo simulations, and mol. dynamics simulations, to the burgeoning area of the hydrogen storage by metal-org. frameworks and covalent-org. frameworks. This review begins with an overview of the theor. methods obtained from previous studies. Then strategies for the improvement of hydrogen storage in the porous materials are discussed in detail. The strategies include appropriate pore size, impregnation, catenation, open metal sites in metal oxide parts and within org. linker parts, doping of alkali elements onto org. linkers, substitution of metal oxide with lighter metals, functionalized org. linkers, and hydrogen spillover.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVamurc%253D&md5=5fdb0abe9382118da44bedd94df18618
      13. 13
        (a) Dincă, M.; Long, J. R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2008, 47, 6766
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13a
        Hydrogen storage in microporous metal-organic frameworks with exposed metal sites
        Dinca, Mircea; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (36), 6766-6779CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Owing to their high uptake capacity at low temp. and excellent reversibility kinetics, metal-org. frameworks are potential solid-state H storage materials. Strategies for increasing the affinity of these materials towards H have been pursued and the binding of H2 to unsatd. metal centers is one of the most promising. The synthetic approaches employed far for producing frameworks with exposed metal sites are discussed as well as the H uptake capacities and binding energies in these materials. Results from expts. that were used to probe independently the metal-H interaction in selected materials are presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtV2iurrF&md5=2f4a240275f7eec477689d67e4fc0606
        (b) Ma, L.; Mihalcik, D. J.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 4610
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13b
        Highly Porous and Robust 4,8-Connected Metal-Organic Frameworks for Hydrogen Storage
        Ma, Liqing; Mihalcik, David J.; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (13), 4610-4612CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Highly porous and robust metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) were constructed based on aroms.-rich octa-carboxylate ligands (I; R = Et, H, Bn) and copper paddle-wheel building units. Each octa-carboxylate ligand is linked to eight copper paddle wheels via the bridging carboxylate groups in a rectangular prismatic fashion to lead to very rare (4,8)-connected networks of the scu topol. The high-connectivity MOFs show remarkably high porosity and framework stability, as evidenced by a perfect agreement between exptl. and theor. surface areas and the maintenance of framework powder x-ray diffraction patterns after solvent removal. These aroms.-rich MOFs exhibit an exceptionally high hydrogen uptake of up to 2.5% at 77 K and 1 atm. This work thus demonstrates the ability to construct highly porous and robust functional MOFs using multidentate bridging ligands of high connectivity. Such a rational synthetic strategy is complementary to the common reliance on high-nuclearity metal clusters for building stable and porous MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXjtlSisLw%253D&md5=bea2b8aad28ca89535414eb878332ccc
        (c) Lu, W. G.; Yuan, D. Q.; Makal, T. A.; Li, J. R.; Zhou, H.-C. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2012, 51, 1580
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13c
        A Highly Porous and Robust (3,3,4)-Connected Metal-Organic Framework Assembled with a 90° Bridging-Angle Embedded Octacarboxylate Ligand
        Lu, Weigang; Yuan, Daqiang; Makal, Trevor A.; Li, Jian-Rong; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2012), 51 (7), 1580-1584, S1580/1-S1580/14CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Herein we report the design and synthesis of a highly porous and robust dicopper(II)-paddle-wheel-based metal-org. framework (PCN-80). To our knowledge, PCN-80 is a rare example of MOF assembled with an octatopic ligand and the first one that features a 90°-bridging-angle subunit. The octatopic ligand 9,9',9'',9'''-([1,1'-biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetrayl)tetrakis(9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylic acid) (H8bttcd) was synthesized by a CuI-catalyzed reaction between di-Me 9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylate and 3,3',5,5'-tetrabromo-1,1'-biphenyl and subsequent hydrolysis with KOH in an overall yield of 30%. This unique ligand has a 90°-angular-dicarboxylate moiety as opposed to the widely used 120°-angular-isophthalate moiety in the construction of MOFs. Solvothermal reaction of H8bttcd and Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O in DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide) in the presence of HBF4 afforded tetragonal-shaped green crystals of PCN-80 with the mol. formula [Cu4(bttcd)(H2O)4]·xDMF.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xnt1Ojuw%253D%253D&md5=575a879b4ec2e25a2af7474b9941b77c

        Exceptionally high H2 storage by a metal-organic polyhedral framework
        Yan, Yong; Lin, Xiang; Yang, Sihai; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroeder, Martin

        The de-solvated polyhedral framework material, NOTT-112, shows an excess H2 uptake of 7.07% between 35 and 40 bar at 77 K, and a total H2 uptake of 10% at 77 bar and 77 K.

        14b
        Metal-Organic Polyhedral Frameworks: High H2 Adsorption Capacities and Neutron Powder Diffraction Studies
        Yan, Yong; Telepeni, Irvin; Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Kockelmann, Winfried; Dailly, Anne; Blake, Alexander J.; Lewis, William; Walker, Gavin S.; Allan, David R.; Barnett, Sarah A.; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (12), 4092-4094CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The metal-org. polyhedral framework complex [Cu3(L)(H2O)3]·16DMF·26H2O (NOTT-112, H6L = 1,3,5-tris(4-(3,5-dicarboxyphenylethynyl)phenyl)benzene) was prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and hydrogen adsorption expts. Neutron powder diffraction expts. on D2-loaded NOTT-112 reveal that the axial sites of exposed Cu(II) ions in the smallest cuboctahedral cages are the 1st, strongest binding sites for D2 leading to an overall discrimination between the two types of exposed Cu(II) sites at the paddlewheel nodes. Thus, the Cu(II) centers within the cuboctahedral cage are the 1st sites of D2 binding with a Cu-D2 distance of 2.23(1) Å.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXis1Oqu7k%253D&md5=215f7876ac3dc27255674de9b72a8095

        14c
        An Isoreticular Series of Metal-Organic Frameworks with Dendritic Hexacarboxylate Ligands and Exceptionally High Gas-Uptake Capacity
        Yuan, Daqiang; Zhao, Dan; Sun, Daofeng; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (31), 5357-5361, S5357/1-S5357/12CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An isoreticular metal-org. framework series with the (3,24)-connected network topol. has been synthesized by using a series of dendritic hexacarboxylate ligands. The framework is stabilized by incorporating microwindows whose size is fixed by the formation of cuboctahedral supported by the isophthalate moieties throughout the framework. Adsorption studies using hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide reveal that they have close to record-high gas adsorption capacities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (d) Farha, O. K.; Yazaydın, A. Ö.; Eryazici, I.; Malliakas, C. D.; Hauser, B. G.; Kanatzidis, M. G.; Nguyen, S. T.; Snurr, R. Q.; Hupp, J. T. Nat. Chem. 2010, 2, 944
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14d
        De novo synthesis of a metal-organic framework material featuring ultrahigh surface area and gas storage capacities
        Farha, Omar K.; Oezguer Yazaydin, A.; Eryazici, Ibrahim; Malliakas, Christos D.; Hauser, Brad G.; Kanatzidis, Mercouri G.; Nguyen, Son-Binh T.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Hupp, Joseph T.
        Nature Chemistry (2010), 2 (11), 944-948CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Metal-org. frameworks, a class of porous hybrid materials built from metal ions and org. bridges, have recently shown great promise for a wide variety of applications. The large choice of building blocks means that the structures and pore characteristics of the metal-org. frameworks can be tuned relatively easily. However, despite much research, it remains challenging to prep. frameworks specifically tailored for particular applications. Here, the authors used computational modeling to design and predictively characterize a metal-org. framework (NU-100) with a particularly high surface area. Subsequent exptl. synthesis yielded a material [Cu3(L)(H2O)3]n (NU-100/PCN-610, H6L = hexatopic carboxylate I), matching the calcd. structure, with a high BET surface area (6,143 m2 g-1). Also, sorption measurements revealed that the material had high storage capacities for H2 (164 mg g-1) and CO2 (2,315 mg g-1) - gases of high importance in the contexts of clean energy and climate alteration, resp. - in excellent agreement with predictions from modeling.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtlWksbjN&md5=706f3b3b6b4cb7d03950103b11ba023e

        High capacity gas storage by a 4,8-connected metal-organic polyhedral framework
        Tan, Chenrong; Yang, Sihai; Champness, Neil R.; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Lewis, William; Schroeder, Martin
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (15), 4487-4489CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The polyhedral complex [Cu4L(H2O)4]solv (NOTT-140, H8L = octacarboxylic acid I) shows a 4,8-connected structure of rare scu topol. comprising octahedral and cuboctahedral cages; desolvated NOTT-140a shows a total CO2 uptake of 314.6 cm3 (STP) cm-3 at 20 bar, 293 K, and a total H2 uptake of 6.0% at 20 bar, 77 K.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjvFSqsrY%253D&md5=9384dcdf85430a5c58812f0fa1ffd280

        14f
        Enhancement of H2 Adsorption in Coordination Framework Materials by Use of Ligand Curvature
        Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Dailly, Anne; Blake, Alexander J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2009), 15 (19), 4829-4835, S4829/1-S4829/15CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Enhancement of H2 adsorption was obsd. in coordination framework materials, an example of which is depicted, by the introduction of phenanthrene and 9,10-dihydrophenanthrene groups into porous CuII-carboxylate framework materials of NbO topol. Solvothermal reaction of the ligands H4L110 ((2,7-phenanthrenediyl)diisophthalic acid) and H4L111 ([2,7-(9,10-dihydrophenanthrenediyl)]diisophthalic acid) with Cu(NO3)2·2.5 H2O in a slightly acidified mixt. of DMF/1,4-dioxane/H2O afforded the solvated framework compds. [Cu2(L110)(H2O)2](DMF)7.5(H2O)5 (NOTT-110) and [Cu2(L111)(H2O)2](DMF)7.5(H2O)5 (NOTT-111), resp. Crystal structure detns. confirmed that NOTT-110 and NOTT-111 have the same NbO framework structure, differing only at the 9 and 10 positions of the phenanthrene group. The BET surface areas for desolvated NOTT-110 and NOTT-111 are 2960 and 2930 m2 g-1, resp. Compared with their Ph analogs, introduction of phenanthrene groups to these porous CuII-carboxylate framework materials leads to an enhancement of H2 adsorption. Thus, the H2 isotherms for desolvated NOTT-110 and NOTT-111 confirm 2.64 and 2.56% total H2 uptake, resp., at 1 bar and 78 K. NOTT-110 shows a high total H2 storage capacity of 7.62% at 55 bar and 77 K (8.5% at satn.) with a total volumetric capacity of 46.8 g L-1 at 55 bar and 77 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXmtVGrt74%253D&md5=97da3fa9bfd88657d18059efc31b85ac
      15. 15
        Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 1304
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386
      16. 16
        (a) Song, C. Catal. Today 2006, 115, 2
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16a
        Global challenges and strategies for control, conversion and utilization of CO2 for sustainable development involving energy, catalysis, adsorption and chemical processing
        Song, Chunshan
        Catalysis Today (2006), 115 (1-4), 2-32CODEN: CATTEA; ISSN:0920-5861. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) has become an important global issue due to the significant and continuous rise in atm. CO2 concns., accelerated growth in the consumption of carbon-based energy worldwide, depletion of carbon-based energy resources, and low efficiency in current energy systems. The barriers for CO2 utilization include: (1) costs of CO2 capture, sepn., purifn., and transportation to user site; (2) energy requirements of CO2 chem. conversion (plus source and cost of co-reactants); (3) market size limitations, little investment-incentives and lack of industrial commitments for enhancing CO2-based chems.; and (4) the lack of socio-economical driving forces. The strategic objectives may include: (1) use CO2 for environmentally-benign phys. and chem. processing that adds value to the process; (2) use CO2 to produce industrially useful chems. and materials that adds value to the products; (3) use CO2 as a beneficial fluid for processing or as a medium for energy recovery and emission redn.; and (4) use CO2 recycling involving renewable sources of energy to conserve carbon resources for sustainable development. The approaches for enhancing CO2 utilization may include one or more of the following: (1) for applications that do not require pure CO2, develop effective processes for using the CO2-concd. flue gas from industrial plants or CO2-rich resources without CO2 sepn.; (2) for applications that need pure CO2, develop more efficient and less-energy intensive processes for sepn. of CO2 selectively without the neg. impacts of co-existing gases such as H2O, O2, and N2; (3) replace a hazardous or less-effective substance in existing processes with CO2 as an alternate medium or solvent or co-reactant or a combination of them; (4) make use of CO2 based on the unique phys. properties as supercrit. fluid or as either solvent or anti-solvent; (5) use CO2 based on the unique chem. properties for CO2 to be incorporated with high atom efficiency' such as carboxylation and carbonate synthesis; (6) produce useful chems. and materials using CO2 as a reactant or feedstock; (7) use CO2 for energy recovery while reducing its emissions to the atm. by sequestration; (8) recycle CO2 as C-source for chems. and fuels using renewable sources of energy; and (9) convert CO2 under either bio-chem. or geol.-formation conditions into "new fossil" energies. Several cases are discussed in more detail. The first example is tri-reforming of methane vs. the well-known CO2 reforming over transition metal catalysts such as supported Ni catalysts. Using CO2 along with H2O and O2 in flue gases of power plants without sepn., tri-reforming is a synergetic combination of CO2 reforming, steam reforming and partial oxidn. and it can eliminate carbon deposition problem and produces syngas with desired H2/CO ratios for industrial applications. The second example is a CO2 "mol. basket" as CO2-selective high-capacity adsorbent which was developed using mesoporous mol. sieve MCM-41 and polyethylenimine (PEI). The MCM41-PEI adsorbent has higher adsorption capacity than either PEI or MCM-41 alone and can be used as highly CO2-selective adsorbent for gas mixts. without the pre-removal of moisture because it even enhances CO2 adsorption capacity. The third example is synthesis of di-Me carbonate using CO2 and methanol, which demonstrates the environmental benefit of avoiding toxic phosgene and a processing advantage. The fourth example is the application of supercrit. CO2 for extn. and for chem. processing where CO2 is either a solvent or a co-reactant, or both. The CO2 utilization contributes to enhancing sustainability, since various chems., materials, and fuels can be synthesized using CO2, which should be a sustainable way in the long term when renewable sources of energy are used as energy input.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XkvF2ltb4%253D&md5=0a8228c4c20eaa16e953493120d9c88b
        (b) Yu, K. M. K.; Curcic, I.; Gabriel, J.; Tsang, S. C. ChemSusChem 2008, 1, 893
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A review concerning recent advances in CO2 capture, storage, fixation, and utilization is given. Topics discussed include: C capture and storage; chem. fixation of CO2 (conversion to fuels [methanol, formic acid, di-Me carbonate, Me formate, higher hydrocarbons, photoredn. of CO2]; CO2 conversion to polymeric/construction materials, CO2 conversion to fine/pharmaceutical chems.); and conclusions.

        Transformation of Carbon Dioxide

        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 107 (6), 2365-2387CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review of synthetic technologies for org. compds. that contain equal to or more than three carbon atoms and use of carbon dioxide as a raw material.         Carbon capture and storage: How green can black be?
        Haszeldine, R. Stuart
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 325 (5948), 1647-1652CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A review. The capture of CO2 at the point of emission from coal- or gas-burning power plants is an attractive route to reducing CO2 emissions into the atm. To commercialize carbon capture, as well as transport of liquefied CO2 and its storage in exploited oil fields or saline formations, many technol., com., and political hurdles remain to be overcome. Urgent action is required if carbon capture and storage is to play a large role in limiting climate change.

        (a) Li, J.-R.; Ma, Y.; McCarthy, M. C.; Sculley, J.; Yu, J.; Jeong, H.-K.; Balbuena, P. B.; Zhou, H.-C. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2011, 255, 1791
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17a
        Carbon dioxide capture-related gas adsorption and separation in metal-organic frameworks
        Li, Jian-Rong; Ma, Yu-Guang; McCarthy, M. Colin; Sculley, Julian; Yu, Jia-Mei; Jeong, Hae-Kwon; Balbuena, Perla B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2011), 255 (15-16), 1791-1823CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Reducing anthropogenic CO2 emission and lowering the concn. of greenhouse gases in the atm. has quickly become one of the most urgent environmental issues of our age. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is one option for reducing these harmful CO2 emissions. While a variety of technologies and methods have been developed, the sepn. of CO2 from gas streams is still a crit. issue. Apart from establishing new techniques, the exploration of capture materials with high sepn. performance and low capital cost are of paramount importance. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of cryst. porous materials constructed by metal-contg. nodes bonded to org. bridging ligands hold great potential as adsorbents or membrane materials in gas sepn. In this paper, we review the research progress (from exptl. results to mol. simulations) in MOFs for CO2 adsorption, storage, and sepns. (adsorptive sepn. and membrane-based sepn.) that are directly related to CO2 capture.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmtVGgur8%253D&md5=e355c975136ff8fc01a97d4f7cb95aa8
        (b) Ma, S. Q.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Commun. 2010, 46, 44
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17b
        Gas storage in porous metal-organic frameworks for clean energy applications
        Ma, Shengqian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (1), 44-53CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review of current status of clean energy applications of porous metal-org. frameworks, including hydrogen storage, methane storage and carbon dioxide capture. Porous metal-org. frameworks have exceptionally high surface areas as well as chem.-tunable structures. A significant tech. challenge has been recognized as the development of a viable method to efficiently trap hydrogen, methane and carbon dioxide gas mols. in a confined space for various applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFektrbI&md5=f68836fe1535bf9cef9bc006a9cc0cad
        (c) Cychosz, K. A.; Ahmad, R.; Matzger, A. J. Chem. Sci. 2010, 1, 293
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17c
        Liquid phase separations by crystalline microporous coordination polymers
        Cychosz, Katie A.; Ahmad, Rashid; Matzger, Adam J.
        Chemical Science (2010), 1 (3), 293-302CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Cryst. microporous coordination polymers (MCPs) are highly ordered, porous materials that have recently seen increasing attention in the literature. Whereas gas phase sepns. using MCPs were extensively studied and reviewed, studies on applications in the liq. phase have lagged behind. This review details the work that has previously been reported on liq. phase sepns. using MCPs. Both enantioselective sepns. and sepns. of complex mixts. were achieved using either adsorptive selectivities or size exclusion effects. Mols. that were adsorbed include those as small as water to large org. dyes. In many cases, MCPs outperform their zeolite and activated carbon counterparts both kinetically and in efficiency of sepn. The future outlook for the field is discussed in the context of current challenges in sepns. technologies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpvFegsLY%253D&md5=4a421bda749665cae2d4fc3801613c82
        (d) Li, J. R.; Kuppler, R. J.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1477
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17d
        Selective gas adsorption and separation in metal-organic frameworks
        Li, Jian-Rong; Kuppler, Ryan J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1477-1504CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Adsorptive sepn. is very important in industry. Generally, the process uses porous solid materials such as zeolites, activated carbons, or silica gels as adsorbents. With an ever increasing need for a more efficient, energy-saving, and environmentally benign procedure for gas sepn., adsorbents with tailored structures and tunable surface properties must be found. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), constructed by metal-contg. nodes connected by org. bridges, are such a new type of porous materials. They are promising candidates as adsorbents for gas sepns. due to their large surface areas, adjustable pore sizes and controllable properties, as well as acceptable thermal stability. This crit. review starts with a brief introduction to gas sepn. and purifn. based on selective adsorption, followed by a review of gas selective adsorption in rigid and flexible MOFs. Based on possible mechanisms, selective adsorptions obsd. in MOFs are classified, and primary relationships between adsorption properties and framework features are analyzed. As a specific example of tailor-made MOFs, mesh-adjustable mol. sieves are emphasized and the underlying working mechanism elucidated. In addn. to the exptl. aspect, theor. investigations from adsorption equil. to diffusion dynamics via mol. simulations are also briefly reviewed. Furthermore, gas sepns. in MOFs, including the mol. sieving effect, kinetic sepn., the quantum sieving effect for H2/D2 sepn., and MOF-based membranes are also summarized (227 refs.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVamurY%253D&md5=cbb650af8ce92526fc8ffd870218bbd0
        (e) Kuppler, R. J.; Timmons, D. J.; Fang, Q. R.; Li, J. R.; Makal, T. A.; Young, M. D.; Yuan, D. Q.; Zhao, D.; Zhuang, W. J.; Zhou, H.-C. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2009, 253, 3042
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17e
        Potential applications of metal-organic frameworks
        Kuppler, Ryan J.; Timmons, Daren J.; Fang, Qian-Rong; Li, Jian-Rong; Makal, Trevor A.; Young, Mark D.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhao, Dan; Zhuang, Wenjuan; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2009), 253 (23-24), 3042-3066CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Metal-org. frameworks have received much attention in recent years esp. as newly developed porous materials. As such, they possess a wide array of potential applications including materials for gas storage, gas/vapor sepn., catalysis, luminescence, and drug delivery. In the review, these potential applications of metal-org. frameworks are examd. and an outlook will be proposed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlagt7zM&md5=4bfb28c8429e134985cd1936ebb79030
        (f) Férey, G.; Serre, C. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1380

        17f
        Large breathing effects in three-dimensional porous hybrid matter: facts, analyses, rules and consequences
        Ferey, Gerard; Serre, Christian
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1380-1399CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This crit. review focuses on a strange behavior of crystd. solid matter: its reversible swelling with large magnitude. This will be of interest for experts in porous solids but also for solid state chemists and physicists. Some examples, classified according to the dimensionality of the inorg. subnetwork, present the general requirements and the structural rules which govern the existence of this phenomenon. Its consequences concern specific applications related to sensors, energy savings, sustainable development and health (100 refs.).

        17g
        Metal-organic framework materials as catalysts
        Lee, Jeong Yong; Farha, Omar K.; Roberts, John; Scheidt, Karl A.; Nguyen, Son Binh T.; Hupp, Joseph T.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1450-1459CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review; a crit. review of the emerging field of MOF-based catalysis is presented. Discussed are examples of: (a) opportunistic catalysis with metal nodes, (b) designed catalysis with framework nodes, (c) catalysis by homogeneous catalysts incorporated as framework struts, (d) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated mol. species, (e) catalysis by metal-free org. struts or cavity modifiers, and (f) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated clusters.
